{"uri": "8243444227", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:07:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:07:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:07:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/gavin-newsom-remove-homeless-encampments-b2585884.html", "title": "Gavin Newsom orders California to remove homeless encampments after SCOTUS ruling", "body": "The order will ask state agencies and departments to create \"clear policies\" that address homeless encampments which could pose a health or safety risk. Newsom asked that the policies be consistent with those adopted by the California Department of Transportation.\n\nThe Department of Transportation has cleared more than 11,000 encampments over the last three years from underneath overpasses, near offramps and more.\n\nThe state will give those people 48 to 72 hours notice and connect them with local service providers and housing. Any personal property will be collected, bagged, tagged and stored for at least 60 days.\n\n\"No more excuses. We've provided the time. We've provided the funds. Now it's time for locals to do their job,\" Newsom wrote on X in response to the order.\n\nIt is the governor's first sweeping effort to tackle California's homelessness problem - something he has made a priority of his governorship.\n\nApproximately 181,000 people in the state are estimated to be homeless, making California home to the largest population of unhoused people in the country.\n\nCities and counties across the state have approached the problem from various angles but with mixed results.\n\nIn Los Angeles, thousands of unhoused people have obtained temporary housing as part of the mayor's initiative but the short-term fix has also led to segregation, police harassment and property destruction.\n\nBut last month the Supreme Court essentially gave cities the go-ahead to enact ordinances that target homelessness by punishing people for sleeping outside on public property.\n\nThe conservative majority of the court said that a set of rules that allow law enforcement to ticket, fine or jail people sleeping outside did not constitute cruel and unusual punishment.\n\nNewsom praised the ruling, saying it would allow officials to \"enforce policies to clear unsafe encampments\" and lifted limitations on \"their ability to deliver on common-sense measures to protect the safety and well-being of our communities.\"\n\nBut human rights groups condemned the ruling, saying it was not a proper solution to homelessness.\n\n\"We cannot arrest our way out of homelessness,\" Scout Katovich, an ACLU attorney in the Trone Center for Justice and Equality, said in a statement last month.\n\n\"It is hard to imagine a starker example of excessive punishment than fining and jailing a person for the basic human act of sleeping,\" Katovich added.\n\nAnn Olivia, the CEO of the National Alliance to End Homelessness said the Supreme Court's ruling set a \"dangerous precedent\" and allowed elected officials to \"shift the burden\" of homelessness solutions on law enforcement.\n\nNewsom's executive order cannot force cities to take action but will serve as a guideline when officials are faced with a homeless encampment that they believe is a health or safety risk.", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Independent"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homelessness", {"uri": "2024-07-433700563", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:44:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:44:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:44:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://foreignaffairs.co.nz/2024/07/26/mil-osi-usa-governor-newsom-orders-state-agencies-to-address-encampments-in-their-communities-with-urgency-and-dignity/", "title": "MIL-OSI USA: Governor Newsom orders state agencies to address encampments in their communities with urgency and dignity", "body": "This executive order directs state agencies to move urgently to address dangerous encampments while supporting and assisting the individuals living in them -- and provides guidance for cities and counties to do the same. The state has been hard at work to address this crisis on our streets. There are simply no more excuses. It's time for everyone to do their part.\n\nGovernor Newsom's executive order directs state agencies and departments to adopt humane and dignified policies to urgently address encampments on state property, including by taking necessary and deliberate steps to notify and support the people inhabiting the encampment prior to removal.\n\nGovernor Newsom has made record-level investments to address the housing crisis, investing over $24 billion across multiple state agencies and departments, including billions of dollars in funding to assist local jurisdictions in providing services and wrap-around support to people living in encampments. In Fiscal Year 2022-2023, these investments helped lift more than 165,000 people out of homelessness and into interim or permanent housing.\n\nCalifornia blueprint\n\nGovernor Newsom's order directs state agencies and departments to adopt policies and plans consistent with the California Department of Transportation's (Caltrans) existing encampment policy. Since July 2021, California has resolved more than 11,000 encampments, and has removed 248,275 cubic yards of debris from encampments along the state right of way in preparation for Clean California projects. Prioritizing encampments that pose a threat to the life, health, and safety of the community, Caltrans provides advance notice of clearance and works with local service providers to support those experiencing homelessness at the encampment, and stores personal property collected at the site for at least 60 days.\n\nThe order encourages local governments to emulate the state's successful model to adopt local policies and to use all available resources, including those provided by the state's historic investments in housing and intervention programs, to address encampments within their jurisdictions.\n\nProposition 1 funding available for local governments\n\nGovernor Newsom also encourages local governments to apply for the newly available $3.3 billion in competitive grant funding from Proposition 1 to expand the behavioral health continuum and provide appropriate care to individuals experiencing mental health conditions and substance use disorders -- with a particular focus on people who are most seriously ill, vulnerable, or homeless.\n\nProposition 1 includes two parts: a $6.4 billion Behavioral Health Bond for treatment settings and housing with services, and historic reform of the Behavioral Health Services Act (BHSA) to focus on people with the most serious illnesses, substance disorders, and housing needs. The state also recently released the Proposition 1 Behavioral Health Services Act: Housing Supports Primer (July 2024) for counties, which explains how to spend the projected $950 million annual BHSA revenue on housing interventions.\n\nUnprecedented investments to support communities\n\nGovernor Newsom is tackling California's homelessness crisis head-on. Since he took office, the state has developed a Statewide Action Plan for Preventing and Ending Homelessness and the Governor has demanded unprecedented accountability from local governments to do their part to end the homelessness crisis through regionally coordinated action plans. The Governor has also pioneered nation-leading homeless and housing reforms and invested more than $24 billion to address this crisis with state and local support, including $4.85 billion for Homeless, Housing Assistance and Prevention Grants for local jurisdictions to prevent and reduce homelessness, $1 billion in Encampment Resolution Funding to assist local jurisdictions in providing services and supports to people living in encampments, and $3.3 billion for Homekey to rapidly expand housing for persons experiencing homelessness.", "source": {"uri": "foreignaffairs.co.nz", {"uri": "8243706267", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:21:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:21:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:20:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/3030477-california-governor-orders-removal-of-homeless-encampments-following-supreme-court-decision", "title": "California Governor Orders Removal of Homeless Encampments Following Supreme Court Decision | Law-Order", "body": "California Governor Gavin Newsom on Thursday announced that the state would commence the removal of homeless encampments following a recent Supreme Court decision supporting anti-camping laws, which penalize those living on the streets.\n\n\"It's time to move with urgency at the local level to clean up these sites, to focus on public health and focus on public safety. There are no longer any excuses,\" Newsom stated in a video posted on X, revealing the new order. California had 180,000 homeless individuals in 2023, more than any other U.S. state, with most sleeping outdoors, according to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development.\n\nThe Supreme Court decision on June 28 reversed a Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ruling that deemed punishing people for sleeping outdoors unconstitutional when no shelter beds are available. As a result, some agencies and local governments hesitated to remove the encampments, fearing legal challenges, while others faced lawsuits after dismantling camps.\n\nGovernor Newsom directed state agencies to prioritize the removal of camps posing health and safety hazards. Agencies are required to provide at least 48 hours' notice to those affected, request social services for them, and store their belongings for at least 60 days. Since July 2021, California's transportation department has eliminated over 11,000 camps under similar policies.\n\nHowever, Divya Shiv of Housing California criticized Newsom's move, arguing that affordable housing is the real solution. Citing a Rand study, she noted that cleanups in Los Angeles didn't reduce homelessness long-term as people returned after a month or two. \"The question remains, where do they go if there isn't enough affordable and supportive housing?\" Shiv challenged.\n\nNewsom's administration reported moving 165,000 homeless individuals into temporary or permanent housing in fiscal year 2022-2023.", "source": {"uri": "8243688684", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:03:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:03:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:02:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c51y7n821myo", "title": "California Gov. Gavin Newsom orders homeless camps dismantled", "body": "\"There are simply no more excuses. It's time for everyone to do their part.\"\n\nCalifornia has some of the highest concentrations of homeless in the country and despite millions of dollars of investment, encampments continue to line sidewalks, beaches and under freeways. A federal report noted the state accounts for nearly half of the country's unsheltered population.\n\nWhile Mr Newsom's order does not require local officials to remove the encampments that are seen throughout urban parts of the state, his administration can threaten to withhold state funds from counties or cities that do not take action aligning with state policy.\n\nCritics and homeless advocates argue that criminalising homelessness does not solve the root issues, and further stigmatises people in need. Dismantling encampments means people can lose all of their possessions, including important legal documents, medications and other necessary items.\n\nSan Francisco, California's fourth most populous city, had previously cheered the Supreme Court decision in the case Grants Pass v Johnson, and has recently said it has already begun to remove tents.\n\nThe governor's order comes as Republicans criticise Democrats for homeless problems that are affecting many American cities, many of which are run by Democratic local governments.\n\nKamala Harris, a native of California's Bay Area who served as San Francisco district attorney before becoming a senator and then vice-president, has recently launched her bid to be the Democratic nominee to run against Republican Donald Trump for president in November's election. Republicans are keen to tie her political record to urban issues, including homelessness, crime and drug use.\n\nMr Newsom, who is also a Democrat, is widely believed to have ambitions for higher office, including the presidency.\n\nCalifornia, with its high cost of housing, had an estimated 180,000 people in 2023 living without permanent shelter, according to an annual report from the US Department of Housing and Urban Development.\n\nHomelessness is on the rise in the US, fuelled in part by chronic shortages of affordable housing. Around 653,000 people did not have homes in 2023, the largest number since tracking began in 2007, according to US government figures.", "source": {"uri": "bbc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-07-433686255", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:24:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:24:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:22:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/justice/supreme-court/article290424039.html", "title": "How a Supreme Court ruling led to Gavin Newsom's order on clearing California homeless camps", "body": "Gov. Gavin Newsom's order to state agencies to adopt policies to evict homeless encampments came a month after the Supreme Court gave California and other states the green light to ban camping on public property.\n\nThe Supreme Court, which has a 6-3 conservative majority, ruled on ideological lines last month that civil and criminal penalties for camping in public areas are not cruel and unusual punishments on homeless people under the Eighth Amendment.\n\nThe 6-3 decision in City of Grants Pass v. Johnson removed blockages from lower court rulings on anti-camping laws in Western states, including California. By siding with the Oregon mountain town of Grants Pass, the Supreme Court allowed state and local officials to enforce laws clearing homeless encampments.\n\nGrants Pass v. Johnson asked whether fining and arresting unhoused people for camping in public areas -- from a parked car to a tent at the park or a blanket on the sidewalk -- when they have nowhere else to go violated the Eighth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. The amendment prohibits \"cruel and unusual punishments.\"\n\nWhat was Grants Pass v. Johnson?\n\nThe case originated from Grants Pass, a southwest Oregon town of about 40,000 people. About a decade ago, its city council instituted fines that could lead to criminal charges for unhoused people sleeping outside, even those using as little as a blanket or cardboard box when they lacked other shelter, in an effort to ban encampments.\n\nGrants Pass has one overnight shelter for adults with 138 beds. But the shelter has a Christian focus and strict restrictions that made it unpalatable or inaccessible to many of the approximately 600 people who were experiencing homelessness in the city.\n\nIn 2018, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, which covers Western states, decided in Martin v. City of Boise that the Eighth Amendment prohibited local governments from criminalizing \"sitting, sleeping, or lying outside on public property for homeless individuals who cannot obtain shelter.\"\n\nThe appellate court relied on a 1962 Supreme Court decision that said the Eighth Amendment prevented criminalizing someone's status -- in Martin v. Boise, the status of homelessness. The 1962 case, Robinson v. California, involved the status of being addicted to drugs.\n\nFollowing the decision in Martin v. Boise, lawyers representing homeless residents sued Grants Pass over the anti-camping ordinances. In 2020, a federal judge in Oregon ruled that due to the lack of shelter, fining and arresting homeless people for sleeping outside with makeshift bedding violated the Eighth Amendment.\n\nIn 2022, the Ninth Circuit agreed. Civil fines that were intertwined with criminal punishments, like the ones in Grants Pass, were blocked there and in Western states, including California.\n\nThe Supreme Court overturned both Ninth Circuit rulings in its decision last month.\n\nHow did the Ninth Circuit rulings affect California?\n\nBefore the Supreme Court decision, some lower court judges citing the Ninth Circuit rulings blocked municipalities from evicting encampments unless there were enough shelter beds for its entire homeless population.\n\nCalifornia officials said the Ninth Circuit decisions were confusing and did not properly distinguish what is voluntary versus involuntary homelessness.\n\nLawmakers from across the state and political spectrum had a strong interest in Grants Pass v. Johnson as California grapples with some of the highest rates of homelessness and housing costs in the United States.\n\nNewsom and others had urged the Supreme Court to hear the case, arguing in legal briefs that lower court rulings had stymied their ability to regulate encampments even when shelter beds were available.\n\nOn Thursday, Newsom directed agencies to remove homeless encampments that pose a risk to \"life, health and safety.\"\n\n\"This executive order directs state agencies to move urgently to address dangerous encampments while supporting and assisting the individuals living in them -- and provides guidance for cities and counties to do the same,\" Newsom said in a statement. \"The state has been hard at work to address this crisis on our streets. There are simply no more excuses. It's time for everyone to do their part.\"\n\nHousing advocates warned that penalizing people for sleeping outside when they have nowhere else to go would perpetuate poverty and worsen homelessness.\n\n\"This is going to be a harmful policy for everyone,\" Eric Tars, policy director at the National Homelessness Law Center, which opposed the court's ruling, said of Newsom's order. \"But there are some people who are going to hurt more, and those are already people already marginalized on racial, gender lines and disabled communities.\"", "source": {"uri": "mcclatchydc.com", {"uri": "8243791971", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:10:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:10:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:09:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.foxnews.com/politics/california-senate-republicans-blast-newsom-pr-stunt-clearing-homeless-camps-convenient-timing", "title": "California Senate Republicans blast Newsom PR stunt on clearing homeless camps as 'convenient timing'", "body": "Podcast host Emily Wilson discusses California's free health care for migrants and crime in the state on 'Fox News @ Night.'\n\nCalifornia Senate Republicans are calling out Gov. Gavin Newsom for what they say is a \"PR stunt,\" after he announced a new initiative to dismantle homeless encampments across the state via an executive order. The Republicans ripped Newsom in a press release after he announced the initiative on Thursday, with his office stating that the governor has ordered \"state agencies and departments to adopt clear policies that urgently address homeless encampments while respecting the dignity and well-being of all Californians.\"\n\n\"It's about damn time! Letting people live and die on the streets or in our parks is unsafe and unsanitary,\" said Senate Minority Leader Brian W. Jones (R-San Diego). \"I introduced a proposal earlier this year that would have provided even greater and more immediate solutions. While I am cautiously optimistic that the governor has finally taken note of the urgency of this problem, albeit many years later than needed, Californians deserve government for the people, not the PR hits.\"\n\nGOV NEWSOM ORDERS HOMELESS ENCAMPMENTS TORN DOWN ACROSS CALIFORNIA: 'NO MORE EXCUSES'\n\nSenate Bill 1011, introduced by Jones and all Senate Republicans this February, was a bipartisan effort that would have gone even further in clearing homeless encampments but was rejected by Democrats in the Senate Committee on Public Safety.\n\nSenate Republicans have introduced a number of bills in recent years to address the rampant and growing California homeless crisis but have been largely met with resistance from Newsom and legislative Democrats.\n\n\"Homelessness is one of the biggest challenges we face today and it is imperative we take swift, decisive and effective action to address it,\" said Senator Roger Niello (R-Fair Oaks). \"This executive order is a good step, but it will require significant follow through to ensure its effectiveness.\"\n\nThe statement from Newsom's office said that the executive order \"directs state agencies and departments to adopt humane and dignified policies to urgently address encampments on state property, including by taking necessary and deliberate steps to notify and support the people inhabiting the encampment prior to removal.\"\n\nThe governor claims that this initiative was spurred by the Supreme Court's decision in Grants Pass v. Johnson last month, which found laws restricting sleeping in public areas did not violate the constitutional restriction against \"cruel and unusual punishment.\"\n\nMASSIVE CALIFORNIA RESIDENTIAL TOWER TO OFFER HOMELESS PRIVATE ROOMS, GYM, CAFE AND MORE AMENITIES\n\n\"The state has been hard at work to address this crisis on our streets,\" Newsom said. \"There are simply no more excuses. It's time for everyone to do their part.\"\n\nThe order is expected to affect tens of thousands of homeless Californians who have set up long-term encampments and occupied entire city blocks with open-air drug use.\n\n\"Big promises. No action. Blame locals. No press. Rinse and repeat,\" GOP Assembly leader James Gallagher wrote in response to Newsom's order in a post on X.\n\nCALIFORNIA GOP LEADERS CALL FOR ACCOUNTABILITY AFTER STATE CAN'T ACCOUNT FOR $24B SPENT ON HOMELESS CRISIS\n\nBack in April, California GOP leaders called for more accountability after an audit indicated that the state spent around $24 billion to tackle the homeless crisis over the past five years but did not consistently track whether the huge outlay of public money did anything to actually improve the problem.\n\nThe state auditor's report found that despite roughly $24 billion spent on homeless and housing programs during the 2018-2023 fiscal years, the problem didn't improve in many cities, according to the state auditor's report.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nAccording to a report from the Public Policy Institute of California, the 2023 Point-in-time (PIT) count released in December estimated that more than 180,000 people were experiencing Gavin Newsom's banning of homeless camps", "body": "The order comes after the recent Supreme Court decision giving local governments more leeway in the removal of homeless encampments.\n\nTop Florida Republicans, including a leading lawmaker and governor's office staff, are applauding Democratic California Gov. Gavin Newsom for his executive order to remove homeless encampments across the Golden State.\n\n\"I'm glad to see Governor Newsom finally accept reality and acknowledge the damage chronic homelessness does to communities and businesses,\" said state Rep. Sam Garrison, R-Fleming Island, in a statement.\n\nGarrison, who is in line to be Florida House speaker in 2026-28, thanked Gov. Ron DeSantis for signing \"Unauthorized Public Camping and Public Sleeping\" (HB 1365), which prohibits local municipalities from allowing people to camp or sleep on public property.\n\n\"The Free State of Florida rejects the siren song of comfortable inaction and instead chooses to lead the way,\" Garrison added.\n\nThe order requires state departments and agencies in California to address encampments on state property. Notices to vacate must be posted at least 48 hours in advance, and personal property will be bagged, tagged and stored for at least 60 days, according to the executive order.\n\n\"No more excuses. We've provided the time. We've provided the funds. Now it's time for locals to do their job,\" Newsom wrote in a post on X.\n\nCalifornia's move to ban homeless encampments comes after the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in late June it's not \"cruel and unusual\" to fine and jail people for being camping and living in public spaces.\n\nDeSantis spokesman Bryan Griffin urged California to make the executive order a state law. \"Keep following the Florida model,\" he posted on X.\n\nChristina Pushaw, the special projects director for DeSantis' communications team, wrote in a social post that she was doubtful Newsom could enforce his executive order.\n\n\"I do hope California is able to clean up the homeless encampments because they're squalid, dangerous, and should not exist in a civilized society. However, as with anything Newsom says, I'll believe it when I see it,\" she wrote.\n\nAs previously reported, the deadline to comply with Florida's new anti-camping law is drawing near, and local municipalities are scrambling to comply.\n\nIn March, the City of Orlando was looking at facilities for an emergency overnight shelter, said spokesperson Ashley Papagni.\n\nAnd the Tampa Bay Times recently reported Pinellas County law enforcement agencies have started to track the location and number of homeless people who sleep outside.\n\nDeSantis has touted the state's anti-camping law as the \"Florida Model,\" a way to keep the state from looking like San Francisco, a city that he had previously said \"collapsed because of leftist policies.\"\n\nDeSantis and Newsom have a fierce rivalry, even debating each other last year on Fox News. Newsom has criticized DeSantis over abortion and immigration, and DeSantis has consistently used California as an example of what Florida isn't.\n\n\"We're basically saying in the state of Florida, a municipality or county is just simply not allowed to embrace San Francisco-style policies,\" DeSantis said in March. \"You can make other choices, but you can't make that choice. Why? Because every time that choice has been made, the result has been destructive.\"\n\nIn 2023, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) counted 18,815 year-round shelter beds in emergency, safe haven and transitional housing in Florida. That same year, the state had 30,756 people experiencing homelessness, with 15,482 people unsheltered.\n\nIn 2023, the Annual Homelessness Assessment Report to Congress by the U.S. Department of {"uri": "8243422066", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:54:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:54:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:48:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/gavin-newsom-issues-order-clear-164203423.html", "title": "Gavin Newsom issues order to clear homeless encampments on California state land", "body": "California Gov. Gavin Newsom directed state agencies on Thursday to dismantle homeless encampments on state land after the U.S. Supreme Court cleared the way for states and cities to move more aggressively.\n\nNewsom's order tells state agencies to identify sites where unhoused people have pitched tents and to make plans to relocate them. The Democratic governor is taking advantage of a high court ruling that overturned a ban on moving people off of public property unless there are sufficient shelter beds for them.\n\n\"The state has been hard at work to address this crisis on our streets,\" Newsom said in a statement. \"There are simply no more excuses.\"\n\nHomelessness has become a paramount issue in California and a political liability for Newsom and other Democrats as voter frustration has grown. Tents have proliferated around sidewalks, parks, and highway underpasses as the number of unhoused people trudges ever upwards.\n\nThe Newsom administration has poured billions of dollars into addressing the issue, but the governor has argued that he was hamstrung by court decisions limiting local governments from acting. He implored the Supreme Court to loosen those restrictions, aligning himself with Republicans and a conservative high court majority that he often opposes.\n\nThursday's executive order expands on Newsom's work more broadly to move people off the street. The California Highway Patrol has acted on thousands of sites in recent years -- figures Newsom has touted as signs of progress -- and the governor has clashed with local governments that he's accused of dragging their feet, threatening to withhold funds.\n\nUnder the order, all state agencies must inventory encampments and formulate plans to begin addressing them. They will need to work with local service providers but, thanks to the Supreme Court decision, they do not need to ensure there are enough shelter beds for everyone before removing an encampment.\n\nOfficials across California are moving swiftly to ramp up encampment clearances. San Francisco Mayor London Breed has promised a \"very aggressive\" sweep and Oakland has begun to move people. Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass has taken a more cautious approach as one of the few Democratic officials in California to criticize the Supreme Court's decision.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", The decision comes after the Supreme Court ruled in favor of a city in Oregon that was giving out tickets to people sleeping outside.\n\nThe court rejected the homeless advocate's arguments that laws aimed at curbing encampments is an example of \"cruel and unusual punishment\" and a violation of the 8th Amendment.\n\nNewsom, a Democrat, said in a statement \"there are simply no more excuses\". He says that now it is up to cities and counties to provide support to people living in encampments. Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass criticized the move saying that the number of homeless in the city went down for the first time in years. She claims that moving people from one neighborhood to another and issuing citations does not solve the problem.", "source": {"uri": "wabcradio.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "77 WABC Radio"}, {"uri": "8243428117", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:54:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:54:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:53:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/campaigns/state/3099125/gavin-newsom-order-dismantle-homeless-encampments/", "title": "Gavin Newsom to order officials to dismantle homeless encampments - Washington Examiner", "body": "In June, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in a 6-3 decision that cities can begin to ban people from sleeping and camping in public areas. The ruling overturned a lower court decision that called it cruel and unusual under the Eighth Amendment to punish those sleeping outside if they had nowhere else to go.\n\nNewsom's move is the most sweeping response to date following that decision.\n\nNewsom's executive order will affect thousands of people in his state, which has the highest housing costs and the highest number of homeless people in the country.\n\nLast year, 180,000 people were homeless. About 123,000 Californians were unsheltered on any given night, according to a recent count. Unlike New York City, which guarantees people the right to housing, California does not.\n\n\"Where do people experiencing homelessness go if every community decides to punish them for their homelessness,\" asked Diane Yentel, president of the National Low Income Housing Coalition.\n\nNewsom's order states agencies should adopt policies to prioritize efforts to address encampments by providing notice to vacate at least 48 hours in advance. They should also contact service providers, collect personal property from removal sites, and store it for at least 60 days.\n\nThe Democratic governor's order also notes that state agencies aren't allowed to simply move campers from one location to another but that they should work with local officials to start housing people and provide services that will allow them to leave the streets for good.\n\nCalifornia has spent billions of dollars to curb its homelessness problem, with little success.\n\nThe streets of San Francisco's Tenderloin district are lined with people who are homeless. Some are addicted to drugs and alcohol while others have mental problems. There are also those who simply can't keep up with the high rental rates in an area that caters to Silicon Valley billionaires.\n\nLos Angeles's Skid Row is home to one of the largest populations of homeless people in the United States. More than 4,400 men, women, and children sleep on drug- and disease-infested streets and under dirty tarps where crime, prostitution, and beatings take place in broad daylight. Skid Row started to take shape in the 1930s and has morphed into a modern-day nightmare.\n\nSince taking office in 2019, Newsom has directed $24 billion to California's homelessness problem. His administration said it moved more than 165,000 people into temporary or permanent housing two years ago but that there is more to be done.\n\n\"There are simply no more excuses,\" he said. \"It's time for everyone to do their part.\"\n\nLast week, San Francisco Mayor London Breed, a Democrat who is facing a tough reelection in November, said city officials would become \"very aggressive and assertive in moving encampments\" starting in August.\n\n\"My hope is that we can clear them all,\" she said at a news conference, adding that homeless people who refuse service have only added to the city's economic decline, which includes businesses abandoning the downtown area and tourists staying away.\n\nAbout 62 miles north of Los Angeles in Lancaster, Republican Mayor R. Rex Parris put it bluntly.\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER\n\n\"I'm warming up the bulldozer,\" he told the New York Times. \"I want the tents away from the residential areas and the shopping centers and the freeways.\"\n\n\"I get that some of these people have fallen on hard times and we have a state-of-the-art shelter with beds available. But the population we're talking about doesn't want a bed,\" he added.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Examiner"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-433666062", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "18:55:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T18:55:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:42:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.tcpalm.com/story/news/politics/2024/07/25/florida-republicans-praise-californias-gavin-newsom-for-homeless-camp-ban/74544691007/", "title": "Top Florida Republicans praise California Gov. Gavin Newsom's banning of homeless camps", "body": "GOP Rep. Sam Garrison, in line to be the next Fla. House speaker, said he was glad Newsom acknowledged 'the damage chronic homelessness does to communities and businesses.'\n\nTop Florida Republicans, including a leading lawmaker and governor's office staff, are applauding Democratic California Gov. Gavin Newsom for his executive order to remove homeless encampments across the Golden State.\n\n\"I'm glad to see Governor Newsom finally accept reality and acknowledge the damage chronic homelessness does to communities and businesses,\" said state Rep. Sam Garrison, R-Fleming Island, in a statement.\n\nGarrison, who is in line to be Florida House speaker in 2026-28, thanked Gov. Ron DeSantis for signing \"Unauthorized Public Camping and Public Sleeping\" (HB 1365), which prohibits local municipalities from allowing people to camp or sleep on public property.\n\n\"The Free State of Florida rejects the siren song of comfortable inaction and instead chooses to lead the way,\" Garrison added.\n\nThe order requires state departments and agencies in California to address encampments on state property. Notices to vacate must be posted at least 48 hours in advance, and personal property will be bagged, tagged and stored for at least 60 days, according to the executive order.\n\n\"No more excuses. We've provided the time. We've provided the funds. Now it's time for locals to do their job,\" Newsom wrote in a post on X.\n\nCalifornia's move to ban homeless encampments comes after the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in late June it's not \"cruel and unusual\" to fine and jail people for being camping and living in public spaces.\n\nDeSantis spokesman Bryan Griffin urged California to make the executive order a state law. \"Keep following the Florida model,\" he posted on X.\n\nChristina Pushaw, the special projects director for DeSantis' communications team, wrote in a social post that she was doubtful Newsom could enforce his executive order.\n\n\"I do hope California is able to clean up the homeless encampments because they're squalid, dangerous, and should not exist in a civilized society. However, as with anything Newsom says, I'll believe it when I see it,\" she wrote.\n\nAs previously reported, the deadline to comply with Florida's new anti-camping law is drawing near, and local municipalities are scrambling to comply.\n\nIn March, the City of Orlando was looking at facilities for an emergency overnight shelter, said spokesperson Ashley Papagni.\n\nAnd the Tampa Bay Times recently reported Pinellas County law enforcement agencies have started to track the location and number of homeless people who sleep outside.\n\nDeSantis has touted the state's anti-camping law as the \"Florida Model,\" a way to keep the state from looking like San Francisco, a city that he had previously said \"collapsed because of leftist policies.\"\n\nDeSantis and Newsom have a fierce rivalry, even debating each other last year on Fox News. Newsom has criticized DeSantis over abortion and immigration, and DeSantis has consistently used California as an example of what Florida isn't.\n\n\"We're basically saying in the state of Florida, a municipality or county is just simply not allowed to embrace San Francisco-style policies,\" DeSantis said in March. \"You can make other choices, but you can't make that choice. Why? Because every time that choice has been made, the result has been destructive.\"\n\nIn 2023, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) counted 18,815 year-round shelter beds in emergency, safe haven and transitional housing in Florida. That same year, the state had 30,756 people experiencing homelessness, with 15,482 people unsheltered.\n\nIn 2023, the Annual Homelessness Assessment Report to Congress by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development found Hardee, Hendry and Highlands counties had the second-highest rate of homelessness in the nation.", "source": {"uri": "tcpalm.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8243372934", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:13:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:13:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:12:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.villagenews.com/story/2024/07/18/news/california-announces-300-million-in-new-funding-to-move-homeless-people-out-of-encampments/76580.html", "title": "California Announces $300 Million in New Funding to Move Homeless People Out of Encampments", "body": "California is making nearly $300 million available to locals to help move even more individuals experiencing unsheltered homelessness from encampments into housing. This new round of funding builds on the $415 million the state has already awarded to cities, counties, and continuums of care to clean up encampments and house people living on the street.\n\nTo date, California has provided $415 million to locals to move people from encampments into housing and get those encampments cleaned up. Now, the state is making an additional $299 million available to locals to build on the state's progress and assist an estimated 10,000 individuals experiencing homelessness. Half of the new grants will be prioritized for encampments on the state right-of-way, helping to ensure the state's highways remain safe and secure for everyone.\n\n\"Since day one, combatting homelessness has been a top priority. Encampments are not safe for the people living in them, or for community members around them. The state is giving locals hundreds of millions of dollars to move people into housing and clean up these persistent and dangerous encampments. And we are doing the same on state land, having removed 5,679 encampments since 2021,\" said Governor Gavin Newsom.\n\nThe California Interagency Council on Homelessness (Cal ICH) is now accepting applications for the $299 million in grants. These competitive grants are available to cities, counties, and continuums of care, and applications will be accepted on a rolling basis until June 30, 2024, or until funds are exhausted. To date, 66 communities have been awarded $414 million from the fund since its inception in 2021.", "source": {"uri": "villagenews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Village News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homelessness", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Homelessness"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "California"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "California"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/County_(United_States)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "County (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gavin_Newsom", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Gavin Newsom"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Real_Estate/Residential", "label": "dmoz/Business/Real Estate/Residential", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Home/Homeowners", "label": "dmoz/Home/Homeowners", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Home/Apartment_Living", "label": "dmoz/Home/Apartment Living", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Home/Apartment_Living/Roommates", "label": "dmoz/Home/Apartment Living/Roommates", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Homeless", "label": "dmoz/Society/Philanthropy/Homeless", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 49}], "image": "https://www.villagenews.com/home/cms_data/dfault/photos/stories/id/8/0/76580/s_top", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9763547", "eventUri": "eng-9763547", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3176470588235294, "wgt": 139, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-433685572", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:23:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:23:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:22:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/supreme-court-ruling-led-gavin-192241926.html", "title": "How a Supreme Court ruling led to Gavin Newsom's order on clearing California homeless camps", "body": "The Supreme Court, which has a 6-3 conservative majority, ruled on ideological lines last month that civil and criminal penalties for camping in public areas are not cruel and unusual punishments on homeless people under the Eighth Amendment.\n\nThe 6-3 decision in City of Grants Pass v. Johnson removed blockages from lower court rulings on anti-camping laws in Western states, including California. By siding with the Oregon mountain town of Grants Pass, the Supreme Court allowed state and local officials to enforce laws clearing homeless encampments.\n\nGrants Pass v. Johnson asked whether fining and arresting unhoused people for camping in public areas -- from a parked car to a tent at the park or a blanket on the sidewalk -- when they have nowhere else to go violated the Eighth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. The amendment prohibits \"cruel and unusual punishments.\"\n\nWhat was Grants Pass v. Johnson?\n\nThe case originated from Grants Pass, a southwest Oregon town of about 40,000 people. About a decade ago, its city council instituted fines that could lead to criminal charges for unhoused people sleeping outside, even those using as little as a blanket or cardboard box when they lacked other shelter, in an effort to ban encampments.\n\nGrants Pass has one overnight shelter for adults with 138 beds. But the shelter has a Christian focus and strict restrictions that made it unpalatable or inaccessible to many of the approximately 600 people who were experiencing homelessness in the city.\n\nIn 2018, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, which covers Western states, decided in Martin v. City of Boise that the Eighth Amendment prohibited local governments from criminalizing \"sitting, sleeping, or lying outside on public property for homeless individuals who cannot obtain shelter.\"\n\nThe appellate court relied on a 1962 Supreme Court decision that said the Eighth Amendment prevented criminalizing someone's status -- in Martin v. Boise, the status of homelessness. The 1962 case, Robinson v. California, involved the status of being addicted to drugs.\n\nFollowing the decision in Martin v. Boise, lawyers representing homeless residents sued Grants Pass over the anti-camping ordinances. In 2020, a federal judge in Oregon ruled that due to the lack of shelter, fining and arresting homeless people for sleeping outside with makeshift bedding violated the Eighth Amendment.\n\nIn 2022, the Ninth Circuit agreed. Civil fines that were intertwined with criminal punishments, like the ones in Grants Pass, were blocked there and in Western states, including California.\n\nThe Supreme Court overturned both Ninth Circuit rulings in its decision last month.\n\nHow did the Ninth Circuit rulings affect California?\n\nBefore the Supreme Court decision, some lower court judges citing the Ninth Circuit rulings blocked municipalities from evicting encampments unless there were enough shelter beds for its entire homeless population.\n\nCalifornia officials said the Ninth Circuit decisions were confusing and did not properly distinguish what is voluntary versus involuntary homelessness.\n\nLawmakers from across the state and political spectrum had a strong interest in Grants Pass v. Johnson as California grapples with some of the highest rates of homelessness and housing costs in the United States.\n\nNewsom and others had urged the Supreme Court to hear the case, arguing in legal briefs that lower court rulings had stymied their ability to regulate encampments even when shelter beds were available.\n\nOn Thursday, Newsom directed agencies to remove homeless encampments that pose a risk to \"life, health and safety.\"\n\n\"This executive order directs state agencies to move urgently to address dangerous encampments while supporting and assisting the individuals living in them -- and provides guidance for cities and counties to do the same,\" Newsom said in a statement. \"The state has been hard at work to address this crisis on our streets. There are simply no more excuses. It's time for everyone to do their part.\"\n\nHousing advocates warned that penalizing people for sleeping outside when they have nowhere else to go would perpetuate poverty and worsen homelessness.\n\n\"This is going to be a harmful policy for everyone,\" Eric Tars, policy director at the National Homelessness Law Center, which opposed the court's ruling, said of Newsom's order. \"But there are some people who are going to hurt more, and those are already people already marginalized on racial, gender lines and disabled communities.\"", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", {"uri": "2024-07-433773054", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:35:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:35:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:18:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/top-news/articles/2024-07-25/governor-newsom-orders-removal-of-california-homeless-encampments", "title": "Governor Newsom Orders Removal of California Homeless Encampments", "body": "(Reuters) - California Governor Gavin Newsom on Thursday said the state would begin removing homeless encampments after a recent Supreme Court decision upheld anti-camping laws used to ticket and fine people living on the streets.\n\n\"It's time to move with urgency at the local level to clean up these sites, to focus on public health and focus on public safety. There are no longer any excuses,\" Newsom said in a video posted on X announcing the new order.\n\nCalifornia had 180,000 homeless people in 2023, more than any other state, and the majority slept outdoors, according to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development.\n\nNewsom's action followed a Supreme Court decision on June 28 reversing a ruling by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals that found punishing people for sleeping outdoors when no shelter beds are available was unconstitutional.\n\nSome agencies and local governments refrained from removing the encampments because of the Ninth Circuit ruling while others faced lawsuits after they dismantled camps.\n\nThe governor told state agencies to prioritize removing camps that pose health and safety risks, provide at least 48 hours notice to the people affected, request social services for them and store their belongings for at least 60 days.\n\nCalifornia's transportation department has removed over 11,000 camps since July 2021 using similar policies.\n\nDivya Shiv of Housing California, which sees affordable housing as the solution, objected to Newsom's move, noting a Rand study showed such cleanups in Los Angeles did not reduce the homeless population long term.\n\n\"After a month or two people would come back, and that's because the question is, where do they go if there isn't enough affordable and supportive housing?\" Shiv said.\n\nNewsom's administration said it moved 165,000 homeless people into temporary or permanent housing in fiscal year 2022-2023.\n\n(Reporting by Liya Cui; editing by Donna Bryson While the governor cannot order local authorities to act, his administration can apply pressure by withholding money for counties and cities.\n\nSUGGESTED:\n\nThe order will give guidance to state agencies on how to remove the thousands of tents and makeshift shelters across the state.\n\n\"We must act with urgency to address dangerous encampments,\" Newsom said in a statement.\n\nThe case was the most significant on the issue to come before the high court in decades and comes as cities across the country have wrestled with the politically complicated issue of how to deal with a rising number of people without a permanent place to live and public frustration over related health and safety issues.\n\nLast month, the LA Homeless Services Authority released its annual \"Greater Los Angeles Homeless Count\" report, which noted that LA saw a slight decline in homelessness.\n\nAccording to that report, LA County saw a slight decline of .27% in overall homelessness countywide as well as a decrease in unsheltered homelessness of 5.1% in the county and 12.7% in the City of Los Angeles.\n\nData revealed there were 75,312 unhoused people in the county and 45,252 unhoused in the city of L.A. in 2024.\n\nOfficials attributed the downward trends to \"unprecedented policy alignment and investments\" made by the city, county, state and federal governments, according to Paul {"uri": "8243559673", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:00:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:00:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:50:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/top-florida-republicans-praise-california-184245134.html", "title": "Top Florida Republicans praise California Gov. Gavin Newsom's banning of homeless camps", "body": "Top Florida Republicans, including a leading lawmaker and governor's office staff, are applauding Democratic California Gov. Gavin Newsom for his executive order to remove homeless encampments across the Golden State.\n\n\"I'm glad to see Governor Newsom finally accept reality and acknowledge the damage chronic homelessness does to communities and businesses,\" said state Rep. Sam Garrison, R-Fleming Island, in a statement.\n\nGarrison, who is in line to be Florida House speaker in 2026-28, thanked Gov. Ron DeSantis for signing \"Unauthorized Public Camping and Public Sleeping\" (HB 1365), which prohibits local municipalities from allowing people to camp or sleep on public property.\n\n\"The Free State of Florida rejects the siren song of comfortable inaction and instead chooses to lead the way,\" Garrison added.\n\nThe order requires state departments and agencies in California to address encampments on state property. Notices to vacate must be posted at least 48 hours in advance, and personal property will be bagged, tagged and stored for at least 60 days, according to the executive order.\n\n\"No more excuses. We've provided the time. We've provided the funds. Now it's time for locals to do their job,\" Newsom wrote in a post on X.\n\nCalifornia's move to ban homeless encampments comes after the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in late June it's not \"cruel and unusual\" to fine and jail people for being camping and living in public spaces.\n\nDeSantis spokesman Bryan Griffin urged California to make the executive order a state law. \"Keep following the Florida model,\" he posted on X.\n\nChristina Pushaw, the special projects director for DeSantis' communications team, wrote in a social post that she was doubtful Newsom could enforce his executive order.\n\n\"I do hope California is able to clean up the homeless encampments because they're squalid, dangerous, and should not exist in a civilized society. However, as with anything Newsom says, I'll believe it when I see it,\" she wrote.\n\nAs previously reported, the deadline to comply with Florida's new anti-camping law is drawing near, and local municipalities are scrambling to comply.\n\nIn March, the City of Orlando was looking at facilities for an emergency overnight shelter, said spokesperson Ashley Papagni.\n\nAnd the Tampa Bay Times recently reported Pinellas County law enforcement agencies have started to track the location and number of homeless people who sleep outside.\n\nDeSantis has touted the state's anti-camping law as the \"Florida Model,\" a way to keep the state from looking like San Francisco, a city that he had previously said \"collapsed because of leftist policies.\"\n\nDeSantis and Newsom have a fierce rivalry, even debating each other last year on Fox News. Newsom has criticized DeSantis over abortion and immigration, and DeSantis has consistently used California as an example of what Florida isn't.\n\n\"We're basically saying in the state of Florida, a municipality or county is just simply not allowed to embrace San Francisco-style policies,\" DeSantis said in March. \"You can make other choices, but you can't make that choice. Why? Because every time that choice has been made, the result has been destructive.\"\n\nIn 2023, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) counted 18,815 year-round shelter beds in emergency, safe haven and transitional housing in Florida. That same year, the state had 30,756 people experiencing homelessness, with 15,482 people unsheltered.\n\nIn 2023, the Annual Homelessness Assessment Report to Congress by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development found Hardee, Hendry and Highlands counties had the second-highest rate of homelessness in the nation.\n\nAna Go\u00f1i-Lessan, state watchdog reporter for the USA TODAY {"uri": "8242089304", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "23:40:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T23:40:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T23:40:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.kqed.org/forum/2010101906457/bay-area-cities-increase-encampment-sweeps-after-supreme-court-grants-pass-ruling", "title": "Bay Area Cities Increase Encampment Sweeps After Supreme Court Grants Pass Ruling | KQED", "body": "Tents on public property including parks and sidewalks have become an enduring part of Bay Area cities which have long struggled with how to balance growing numbers of unsheltered people with keeping public areas clean and accessible. A recent U.S. Supreme Court decision in the Grants Pass v. Johnson case has made it easier for cities to clear out homeless encampments without first offering shelter options. Homeless advocates say the decision will usher in more policing and criminalization of unhoused people and shift away resources from moving people into permanent housing. Already, San Francisco Mayor Breed said the city would be \"very aggressive and assertive in moving encampments\" starting next month to enforce public safety. We'll talk about Bay Area cities' plans for responding to homeless encampments in the wake of the Grants Pass ruling.", "source": {"uri": "kqed.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "KQED"}, "authors": {"uri": "8240383262", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "02:05:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T02:05:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T02:05:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.zerohedge.com/political/after-high-court-ruling-san-francisco-prepares-clear-homeless-camps", "title": "After High Court Ruling, San Francisco Prepares To Clear Homeless Camps", "body": "Authored by Travis Gillmore via The Epoch Times (emphasis ours),\n\nAfter last month's U.S. Supreme Court ruling that gave cities a green light to enforce laws and clear homeless camps, San Francisco is now crafting policies to allow officials to begin sweeping encampments, according to Mayor London Breed's July 19 newsletter.\n\n\"Our goal is to bring people indoors -- camping or living on our streets isn't safe for our community, residents, and people in need of support,\" she said. \"San Francisco is a city that prioritizes compassion, and we will continue to lead with services, but we cannot allow for people to refuse services and shelter when offered and available.\"\n\nOfficials are contemplating options with the city attorney's office and more information will be shared soon, according to Ms. Breed.\n\nThe high court's decision -- related to a lower court's ruling on a case known as Grants Pass that blocked cities from clearing encampments -- now allows municipalities to enforce laws against sleeping, loitering, and lodging on public property when people reject attempts to help them.\n\n\"This decision by the Supreme Court will help cities like San Francisco manage our public spaces more effectively and efficiently,\" Ms. Breed said in a June 28 press release. \"This decision recognizes that cities must have more flexibility to address challenges on our streets.\"\n\nShe said discussions underway aim to reduce homelessness while finding people mental health treatment and services to improve the quality of life for all San Franciscans.\n\n\"[Illegal camping] is not healthy, safe, or compassionate for people on the street, and it's not acceptable for our neighborhoods,\" Ms. Breed said.\n\nOne San Francisco local said he supports increased enforcement because of what he described as \"filthy\" conditions in some areas.\n\n\"The city has become known for feces on the sidewalks and dirty streets,\" John Walker told The Epoch Times July 22. \"Something needs to be done.\"\n\nAfter the high court's ruling was announced in June, the state's Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals quickly moved to discontinue the injunction blocking homeless camp sweeps.\n\nSan Francisco City Attorney David Chiu said the legal changes will allow the city to better manage its streets and improve public safety.\n\n\"This will give our city more flexibility to provide services to unhoused people while keeping our streets healthy and safe,\" Mr. Chiu said in a July 8 press release. \"It will help us address our most challenging encampments, where services are often refused and re-encampment is common.\"\n\nSome homeless advocates argued the new policies could hurt people living on the street.\n\n\"Penalizing individuals, including many with mental health and other disabilities, for merely trying to live is not only cruel but also counterproductive,\" Marlene Sallo, executive director of the National Disability Rights Network, said in a June 28 press release. \"Cities are now further emboldened to ignore effective housing-based solutions, opting instead to punish those with no alternative but to sleep on the streets.\"\n\nShe called on the federal government to provide resources for homeless individuals.\n\n\"Too often a lack of housing in the community leaves people with disabilities stuck in institutions or worse, homeless,\" Ms. Sallo said. \"Affordable and accessible housing is a critical and necessary component for people with disabilities to live independent and fulfilling lives in the community.\"\n\nOther nonprofits agreed and criticized the ruling and discussions about enforcing illegal camping laws.\n\n\"Arresting or fining people for trying to survive is expensive, counterproductive, and cruel,\" Jesse Rabinowitz, campaign and communications director at the National Homelessness Law Center, said in the disability network's press release.\n\nShe added that the \"inhumane\" ruling \"will make homelessness worse.\"\n\n\"Cities are now even more empowered to neglect proven housing-based solutions and to arrest or fine those with no choice but to sleep outdoors,\" Ms. Rabinowitz said. \"While we are disappointed, we are not surprised that this Supreme Court ruled against the interests of our poorest neighbors.\"\n\nIn the 6-3 ruling, Supreme Court justices were split on how best to proceed.\n\n\"Homelessness is complex. Its causes are many,\" Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch, author of the majority opinion, wrote in the ruling. \"People will disagree over which policy responses are best ... nor can a handful of federal judges begin to 'match' the collective wisdom the American people possess in deciding 'how best to handle' a pressing social question like homelessness.\"\n\nIn a dissenting opinion, Justice Sonia Sotomayor said that sleeping outside is the only option for some people.\n\n\"Sleep is a biological necessity, not a crime,\" she wrote.\n\nGov. Gavin Newsom said the ruling gives state and local officials the authority to enforce policies that will benefit Californians.\n\n\"This decision removes the legal ambiguities that have tied the hands of local officials for years and limited their ability to deliver on common-sense measures to protect the safety and well-being of our communities,\" he said in a June 28 press release.\n\nHe also said the state will continue to treat all individuals with compassion.\n\n\"California remains committed to respecting the dignity and fundamental human needs of all people and the state will continue to work with compassion to provide individuals experiencing homelessness with the resources they need to better their lives,\" Mr. Newsom said.", "source": {"uri": "zerohedge.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8240037757", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "19:48:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T19:48:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T19:47:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/us/after-high-court-ruling-san-francisco-prepares-to-clear-homeless-camps-5692315", "title": "After High Court Ruling, San Francisco Prepares to Clear Homeless Camps", "body": "After last month's U.S. Supreme Court ruling that gave cities a green light to enforce laws and clear homeless camps, San Francisco is now crafting policies to allow officials to begin sweeping encampments, according to Mayor London Breed's July 19 newsletter.\n\n\"Our goal is to bring people indoors -- camping or living on our streets isn't safe for our community, residents, and people in need of support,\" she said. \"San Francisco is a city that prioritizes compassion, and we will continue to lead with services, but we cannot allow for people to refuse services and shelter when offered and available.\"\n\nOfficials are contemplating options with the city attorney's office and more information will be shared soon, according to Ms. Breed.\n\nThe high court's decision -- related to a lower court's ruling on a case known as Grants Pass that blocked cities from clearing encampments -- now allows municipalities to enforce laws against sleeping, loitering, and lodging on public property when people reject attempts to help them.\n\nShe said discussions underway aim to reduce homelessness while finding people mental health treatment and services to improve the quality of life for all San Franciscans.\n\n\"[Illegal camping] is not healthy, safe, or compassionate for people on the street, and it's not acceptable for our neighborhoods,\" Ms. Breed said.\n\nOne San Francisco local said he supports increased enforcement because of what he described as \"filthy\" conditions in some areas.\n\n\"The city has become known for feces on the sidewalks and dirty streets,\" John Walker told The Epoch Times July 22. \"Something needs to be done.\"\n\nAfter the high court's ruling was announced in June, the state's Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals quickly moved to discontinue the injunction blocking homeless camp sweeps.\n\nSan Francisco City Attorney David Chiu said the legal changes will allow the city to better manage its streets and improve public safety.\n\nSome homeless advocates argued the new policies could hurt people living on the street.\n\nShe called on the federal government to provide resources for homeless individuals.\n\n\"Too often a lack of housing in the community leaves people with disabilities stuck in institutions or worse, homeless,\" Ms. Sallo said. \"Affordable and accessible housing is a critical and necessary component for people with disabilities to live independent and fulfilling lives in the community.\"\n\nOther nonprofits agreed and criticized the ruling and discussions about enforcing illegal camping laws.\n\n\"Arresting or fining people for trying to survive is expensive, counterproductive, and cruel,\" Jesse Rabinowitz, campaign and communications director at the National Homelessness Law Center, said in the disability network's press release.\n\nShe added that the \"inhumane\" ruling \"will make homelessness worse.\"\n\n\"Cities are now even more empowered to neglect proven housing-based solutions and to arrest or fine those with no choice but to sleep outdoors,\" Ms. Rabinowitz said. \"While we are disappointed, we are not surprised that this Supreme Court ruled against the interests of our poorest neighbors.\"\n\nIn the 6-3 ruling, Supreme Court justices were split on how best to proceed.\n\n\"Homelessness is complex. Its causes are many,\" Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch, author of the majority opinion, wrote in the ruling. \"People will disagree over which policy responses are best ... nor can a handful of federal judges begin to 'match' the collective wisdom the American people possess in deciding 'how best to handle' a pressing social question like homelessness.\"\n\nIn a dissenting opinion, Justice Sonia Sotomayor said that sleeping outside is the only option for some people.\n\n\"Sleep is a biological necessity, not a crime,\" she wrote.\n\nGov. Gavin Newsom said the ruling gives state and local officials the authority to enforce policies that will benefit Californians.\n\nHe also said the state will continue to treat all individuals with compassion.\n\n\"California remains committed to respecting the dignity and fundamental human needs of all people and the state will continue to work with compassion to provide individuals experiencing homelessness with the resources they need to better their lives,\" Mr. Newsom said.", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "www.theepochtimes.com"}, Gavin Newsom orders homeless camps cleared", "body": "\"Clearing encampments is not going to reduce homelessness. It's shifting it around,\" Sullivan said. \"The presence of encampments speaks to the need for more efforts to both prevent and reduce homelessness.\"\n\nResearch shows that the two most effective ways to prevent and reduce homelessness are emergency financial assistance and permanent supportive housing, which includes services to help with substance abuse or other issues, Sullivan said. While such approaches are expensive, he said, they're more effective than clearing encampments because \"if you're not providing a path to housing stability for those who are homeless, you're just moving the issue around.\"", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Post"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reis_thebault@washingtonpost.com", "name": "Reis Thebault", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "molly_hennessy_fiske@washingtonpost.com", "name": "Molly Hennessy-Fiske", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homelessness", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Homelessness"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supportive_housing", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Supportive housing"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Health/Addictions/Substance_Abuse", "label": "dmoz/Health/Addictions/Substance Abuse", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Health", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Health", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Home/Homeowners", "label": "dmoz/Home/Homeowners", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Health/Teen_Health/Teen_Pregnancy", "label": "dmoz/Health/Teen Health/Teen Pregnancy", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Support_Groups/Twelve_Step", "label": "dmoz/Society/Support Groups/Twelve Step", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/CL2RJVAVDEI65E5V7EKZPZ76IM_size-normalized.jpg&w=1440", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9763547", "eventUri": "eng-9763547", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1372549019607843, "wgt": 121, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-433560121", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:46:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:46:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:42:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://www.politico.com/news/2024/07/25/gavin-newsom-homeless-encampments-california-00171157", "title": "Gavin Newsom issues order to clear homeless encampments on California state land", "body": "\"The state has been hard at work to address this crisis on our streets,\" Newsom said in a statement. \"There are simply no more excuses.\"\n\nHomelessness has become a paramount issue in California and a political liability for Newsom and other Democrats as voter frustration has grown. Tents have proliferated around sidewalks, parks, and highway underpasses as the number of unhoused people trudges ever upwards.\n\nThe Newsom administration has poured billions of dollars into addressing the issue, but the governor has argued that he was hamstrung by court decisions limiting local governments from acting. He implored the Supreme Court to loosen those restrictions, aligning himself with Republicans and a conservative high court majority that he often opposes.\n\nThursday's executive order expands on Newsom's work more broadly to move people off the street. The California Highway Patrol has acted on thousands of sites in recent years -- figures Newsom has touted as signs of progress -- and the governor has clashed with local governments that he's accused of dragging their feet, threatening to withhold funds.\n\nUnder the order, all state agencies must inventory encampments and formulate plans to begin addressing them. They will need to work with local service providers but, thanks to the Supreme Court decision, they do not need to ensure there are enough shelter beds for everyone before removing an encampment.\n\nOfficials across California are moving swiftly to ramp up encampment clearances. San Francisco Mayor London Breed has promised a \"very aggressive\" sweep and Oakland has begun to move people. Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass has taken a more cautious approach as one of the few Democratic officials in California to criticize the Supreme Court's decision.", "source": {"uri": "politico.com",
